moves.1. d4 d5: The Queen's pawn game. My second choice opening as black, as I can free up a bishop, and my queen has partial freedom.
moves.2. e3: The Stonewall attack. His light-square bishop is now free, and his dark-square one now has restricted freedom...
moves.2... Nf6: ...so I get ahead on development with my knight, keeping with the Stonewall attack.
moves.3. Nf3: He now brings out his own kingside knight to get level on development...
moves.3... Nc6: ...so I bring out my other knight to get back ahead.
moves.4. Bd3 Nb4: I advance my knight further to attack the bishop, limiting its options...
moves.5. a3 Nxd3+ 6. Qxd3: ...and decide to trade the pieces, as the bishop has a wider range, although it did bring out the queen...
moves.6... e6: ...so I free up my kingside bishop, limiting the queenside bishop's freedom...
moves.7. b3: ...and he's now hoping to fianchetto his remaining bishop...
moves.7... c5: ...and I decide to attack his queen's pawn to attempt to create some space...
moves.8. Bb2: ...and he fianchettos his bishop, as I anticipated...
moves.9... Qe7 10. Nbd2 a6: I thought it was important to prevent a queen check on b5, so I move up my QRP to cover the square...
moves.11. O-O Bd7: ...and I decide it's time to get a bishop out...
moves.13. c4: ...but he covers it with a pawn...
moves.13... dxc4 14. Nxc4: ...so we trade pawns, and he uses his knight to protect his queen...
moves.14... Bxc4 15. Rxc4: ...and we trade the two pieces, but it allowed his rook onto the attack...
moves.15... Qd7: ...so I move my queen and free my other bishop...
moves.16. Rfc1: ...but I'm not too worried about his rooks being connected, as my queen and one of my rooks guard the c8 square...
moves.18. d5: Why did he move his pawn...
moves.18... exd5: ...when I could accept it with my pawn, which is now too well defended?
moves.19. Rh4 g6: This was the fatal error. I didn't realise that my KNP was the only piece defending my knight: I was trying to give my king an escape route should a queen/rook land on his starting rank, although it is guarded by both rooks...
moves.20. Bxf6: ...but not only does the bishop capture my exposed knight, it also blocks off the escape route. I'm suddenly in deep trouble...
moves.20... Rac8: ...so I contest the open file with one of my rooks. I maybe moved the wrong one, as my king cannot move at all...
moves.21. Qd2 Rxc1+ 22. Qxc1: ...and we end up exchanging the rooks.
moves.22... Rc8: I move my remaining rook to attck his queen...
moves.23. Qh6: ...but she moves down to close in on my king...
moves.23... Qc6 24. Qxh7+: ...and I resign after this move, as I could only do Kf8, which would have resulted in mate on the next move: Qh8#. The moral of the story? One mistake can cost you a tight game, so be careful with your moves.
